children.name: Identify different places to consult in order to select an interesting topic
Explore general information sources to increase familiarity with the topic and align it to existing resources
Lesson Plan: Special Collections Mining Exercise
Define and use limiters in order to construct a research question that is neither too broad nor too narrow for the length of the paper and research timeline
Formulate a discipline specific research question and continually reevaluate it as the research process progresses
Construct multiple research questions they will try to answer that relate to their overall topic in order to determine their information need
Develop an awareness that the discovery and creation of knowledge is a dynamic process that evolves over time
Formulate a hypothesis and look at multiple perspectives to create a robust research paper
Recognize the difference between a natural language search and a keyword search and identify where they are best used
Find and use general information resources to identify keywords within the topic area
Lesson Plan: Special Collections Mining Exercise
Construct multiple keyword searches using synonyms and varying the search syntax
Assess and modify the search based on the usefulness of the results in order to focus and refine the search
Use advanced searching (i.e. truncation, wildcard, NOT) in order to narrow or expand the search based on the assessment of the results
Articulate different aspects - author, publisher, date - and integrate these aspects into a comprehensive evaluation; one aspect alone does not define value
Identify the usefulness as well as the limitations of unmediated sources (i.e. social media, blogs) in order to use them when appropriate
Evaluate sources based on disciplinary standards.
Identify the difference between primary and secondary resources in the context of a variety of disciplines

Incorporate materials beyond secondary sources in their work in order to support and demonstrate original thinking
Lesson Plan: Exploring the Archives and Special Collections
Recognize the shifting nature of primary sources in order to use them appropriately within the context of the research question
Identify how specific disciplines collect and format data in order to follow these standards in their own data collection and data visualization
Identify specific types of primary sources (testimony, census data, stock market data) in order to provide the best evidence to support an argument or answer a research question
Identify the scope and nature of a work (e.g., abstract vs. full article) in order to identify the limitations of its use
Recognize when an author is quoting or using the work of others in order to avoid using or citing content without the correct attribution
Identify the main arguments in a source in order to write a summary
Students evaluate the main arguments of a source based on their own knowledge to raise new research questions
When to Use What Research Tools and the Value of Each One
Identifies and uses general purpose databases, (i.e. EBSCO, Proquest, JSTOR)
Student matches information needs and search strategies to appropriate search tools
Identifies and uses subject specific databases (i.e. PsychInfo, DRAM, Accessible Archives)
Identifies and uses advanced search techniques in discovery and online search platforms when applicable in order to find relevant sources
Identify the parts of common (i.e. books, articles, web pages) example citations and copy that format in order to write other citations for items that are the same type of source
Articulate why citations are used in academic research and writing, and why and how styles differ among the disciplines
Create footnotes, endnotes, or in-text citations, as dictated by the citation style they have chosen or been instructed to use
Identify the parts of uncommon citations (i.e. manuscript images, original research: focus groups/interviews) in order to construct more complicated citations
Uses advanced features of citation software in order to organize research and to create and manage notes and bibliographies
Engaging with the Scholarly Conversation to Find Significance
Students engage with their topic within the scholarly conversation inside and outside of the classroom in order to find the gaps in the conversation and contribute something new

Lesson Plan: Going To The Gallery
Students examine a source of information to determine the point of view in order to interpret bias

Students engage with the scholarly conversation looking for alternative points of view in order to better support their claims

Recognize and utilize a variety of information types appropriate to their topic

Lesson Plan: Going To The Gallery
